title: Quotation of the Day: For Black NASCAR Fans, It Can Be Lonely at the Track
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 28, 2020.
content: “We have a flag. It’s the United States flag. I’m cool with that one.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Elijah Walker
title: Coronavirus Surge, Mississippi, Stonewall Inn: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Herrman
title: TikTok Is Shaping Politics. But How?
description: Two researchers have studied political expression on the app since the Musical.ly era. Here’s what they found.
content: As a place where millions of young Americans perform and explore their identities in public, TikTok has become a prominent venue for ideological formation, political activism and trolling. It has homegrown pundits, and despite its parent company’s reluctance to being involved with politics — the service does not allow political ads — it has attracted interest from campaigns. It is also a space where people can be gathered and pressed into action quickly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt, Michael Schwirtz and Charlie Savage
title: Biden Criticizes Trump Over Intelligence on Russian Bounties on U.S. Troops
description: The White House denied that President Trump was briefed on the classified assessment, even though his staff has been discussing the matter since March.
content: WASHINGTON — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. assailed President Trump on Saturday for failing to punish Russia for offering bounties to the Taliban to kill American troops in Afghanistan, while the White House denied that Mr. Trump had been briefed on the months-old classified intelligence assessment about Russia’s activities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Tiksa Negeri
title: African Migrants in Yemen Scapegoated for Coronavirus Outbreak
description: Migrants say Houthi militias that control northern Yemen are brutally forcing them out of their territory and into dangerous situations.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Yemeni militiamen rumbled up to the settlement of Al Ghar in the morning, firing their machine guns at the Ethiopian migrants caught in the middle of somebody else’s war. They shouted at the migrants: Take your coronavirus and leave the country, or face death.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Man Who Saw America’
description: Chronicling the human condition with one of the most influential photographers in history.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Museum of the City of New York: Reduced but Reopening
description: After layoffs, furloughs and salary cuts, the museum prepares to reopen with a reduced budget and will present an exhibition about the pandemic.
content: Near the top of New York’s Museum Mile, north of the Cooper Hewitt, a gem from the Gilded Age, and the Guggenheim, itself a Frank-Lloyd-Wright-work-of-art, and the classical majesty of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, sits the Museum of the City of New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: Chief Beaten by Police Is Longtime Fighter for Indigenous Rights
description: Allan Adam leads a Dene nation that famously fought the Canadian government and oil lobby in its territory.
content: TORONTO — He survived Canada’s notoriously abusive schools for Indigenous children and went on to lead his own nation. He battled governments and oil giants over the pollution of his traditional territory, garnering him the praise and admiration of Desmond Tutu, Greta Thunburg and celebrities like Leonardo DiCaprio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and David Gelles
title: Boeing Gets Go-Ahead for Test Flights of Its Troubled 737 Max
description: The flights, which could begin as soon as Monday, are a major step in getting the plane flying again.
content: Boeing has received Federal Aviation Administration approval to start test flights of its 737 Max to demonstrate that it can fly safely with new flight control software. The flights, which could begin as soon as Monday, represent a major step in the company’s effort to get its best-selling plane flying again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns and Katie Glueck
title: Trump Faces Mounting Defections From a Once-Loyal Group: Older White Voters
description: No Democrat has won or broken even with voters over 65 in two decades. But seniors’ dismay about President Trump could change that.
content: Clifford Wagner, an 80-year-old Republican in Tucson, Ariz., never cared for President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape and Monique Jaques
title: The Lost Spring
description: For many young athletes, senior night is the last act of the last season of their high school careers, and their days as competitive athletes. But how do you celebrate after the coronavirus rewrites the story?
content: UNION, N.J. — At high schools across America, senior night is bittersweet even in the best of times. This year, it became just another milestone, alongside senior proms and graduation ceremonies, erased from the calendar by the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: ‘We Could Be Feeling This for the Next Decade’: Virus Hits College Towns
description: Opening bars and bringing back football teams have led to new outbreaks. Communities that evolved around campuses face potentially existential losses in population, jobs and revenue.
content: DAVIS, Calif. — The community around the University of California, Davis, used to have a population of 70,000 and a thriving economy. Rentals were tight. Downtown was jammed. Hotels were booked months in advance for commencement. Students swarmed to the town’s bar crawl, sampling the trio of signature cocktails known on campus as “the Davis Trinity.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliana Kim and Amr Alfiky
title: How the Floyd Protests Turned Into a 24-Hour ‘Occupy City Hall’ in N.Y.
description: Rain or shine, hundreds of protesters have camped outside City Hall around the clock, refusing to leave until the police budget is cut.
content: It started on Tuesday night when about 100 protesters began occupying City Hall Park in Lower Manhattan — with some spending the night — in an effort to draw more focus to their demand for deep budget cuts to the Police Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri and Michael Gold
title: How the Virus and Protests Changed a 50-Year Celebration of Pride
description: A quiet event marked the 50th anniversary of the first Pride parade, but a counter parade drew a large contingent, and some protesters clashed with police.
content: Not six months ago, the idea of this year’s Pride March in New York City, on the 50th anniversary of the first parade, would have conjured images of colorful floats, elaborate costumes and hundreds of thousands of revelers packed into city streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti, Charlie Savage and Adam Goldman
title: How Michael Flynn’s Defense Team Found Powerful Allies
description: A lawyer for the former national security adviser turned to the attorney general for help, and he delivered, months before a pair of appellate judges handed Mr. Flynn another legal victory.
content: WASHINGTON — Sidney Powell, a firebrand lawyer whose pugnacious Fox News appearances had earned her numerous private phone conversations with President Trump, sent a letter last year to Attorney General William P. Barr about her soon-to-be new client, Michael T. Flynn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: In ‘And She Could Be Next,’ Women of Color Take on Politics
description: The two-part documentary, which follows the campaigns of several female politicians of color and the communities that rally with them, shows what a systemic shift actually looks like.
content: When the directors Grace Lee and Marjan Safinia talk about their new two-part documentary series, “And She Could Be Next,” they compare the process of getting it greenlit to mounting a political campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Horton
title: Taiwan Celebrates Pride With a Public Parade
description: Hundreds joined a march in Taipei, making it one of the few places in the world to proceed with such an event during the coronavirus pandemic.
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — With the coronavirus pandemic making large gatherings impossible in many places, the biggest Pride events around the globe were mostly forced to scale back or move online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Marie Fazio
title: 2 Dead in Shooting at Walmart Distribution Center in California, Including Gunman
description: An employee at the center in Red Bluff, Calif., said he had heard 50 to 60 shots as he and other employees fled the building.
content: A shooting on Saturday by a former worker at a Walmart distribution center in Red Bluff, Calif., left an employee dead and several others injured, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘We Noticed a Man Who Was Standing in the Street Near the Curb’
description: Saving a parking space, an empty seat on a crowded bus and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Mississippi Votes to Remove Confederate Emblem From State Flag
description: Mississippi state legislators voted, 85 to 34, to remove the state’s flag from its Capitol and begin creating a new flag that no longer contains the Confederate battle emblem.
content: Mississippi state legislators voted, 85 to 34, to remove the state’s flag from its Capitol and begin creating a new flag that no longer contains the Confederate battle emblem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron and Sheila Kaplan
title: White House Blames Rise in Virus Cases on More Testing, as Experts Dispute the Claim
description: Vice President Mike Pence and the nation’s top health official, Alex M. Azar II, continued to assert on Sunday that reopenings in many states were not causing the sharp rises in coronavirus cases.
content: Vice President Mike Pence and the nation’s top health official, Alex M. Azar II, continued to assert on Sunday that reopenings in many states were not causing the sharp rises in coronavirus cases, but rather that increased testing was uncovering more and more infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Johnson
title: Excavating Chinese History, One Harrowing Film at a Time
description: The work of Hu Jie, who has made more than 30 movies, is little known even in China. The release of “Spark” and “The Observer” should make him better known abroad.
content: For more than 20 years, the filmmaker Hu Jie has been trawling the deep waters of Chinese history to create a series of harrowing documentaries about the early years of Communist Party rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Brantley
title: ‘Lungs’ Review: Claire Foy and Matt Smith Chase Love in the Dark
description: In Duncan Macmillan’s play, streaming live from the Old Vic, the stars of “The Crown” play a contradictory couple in an age of isolation.
content: The woman and man who make up the entire cast of Duncan Macmillan’s “Lungs,” which is streaming in a beautifully acted (and socially distanced) live production from London’s Old Vic Theater, are people who seldom think before they talk. Feelings — big, sloppy, mixed, unedited, self-incriminating feelings — slosh out of them like the contents of overfilled, foaming beer mugs on a wobbly tray.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Yes, Even George Washington
description: Slavery was a cruel institution that can’t be excused by its era.
content: On the issue of American slavery, I am an absolutist: enslavers were amoral monsters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: U.S. Virus Surge, Hong Kong, Pride: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Global Death Toll Now Tops 500,000
description: Vice President Mike Pence asserts that increased testing explains a surge in cases, but experts and evidence say otherwise. Houston’s top official has self-quarantined.
content: The global total of deaths passed 500,000 on Sunday, according to a New York Times database, while the number of confirmed cases surpassed 10 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Elaina Plott
title: How the Trump Campaign Is Drawing Obama Out of Retirement
description: More than three years after his exit, the 44th president of the United States is back on a political battlefield he longed to leave.
content: Just after Donald J. Trump was elected president, Barack Obama slumped in his chair in the Oval Office and addressed an aide standing near a conspicuously placed bowl of apples, emblem of a healthy-snacking policy soon to be swept aside, along with so much else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt, Adam Goldman and Nicholas Fandos
title: Spies and Commandos Warned Months Ago of Russian Bounties on U.S. Troops
description: The recovery of large amounts of American cash at a Taliban outpost in Afghanistan helped tip off U.S. officials. It is believed that at least one U.S. troop death was the result of the bounties.
content: WASHINGTON — United States intelligence officers and Special Operations forces in Afghanistan alerted their superiors as early as January to a suspected Russian plot to pay bounties to the Taliban to kill American troops in Afghanistan, according to officials briefed on the matter. They believed at least one U.S. troop death was the result of the bounties, two of the officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Mississippi Lawmakers Vote to Retire State Flag Rooted in the Confederacy
description: The flag, which has flown since 1894, is poised to come down, becoming yet another emblem of the Confederacy to be removed across the South.
content: JACKSON, Miss. — Mississippi lawmakers voted on Sunday to bring down, once and for all, the state flag dominated by the Confederate battle emblem that has flown for 126 years, adding a punctuation point to years of efforts to take down relics of the Confederacy across the South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: 4 San Jose Officers Put on Leave Amid Probe Into Racist Facebook Posts
description: Officials are investigating inflammatory remarks, including anti-Muslim comments, by current and former police officers in a private Facebook group.
content: Four police officers in San Jose, Calif., have been placed on administrative leave after an anonymous blog post accused retired and current officers of posting racist and anti-Muslim comments in a private Facebook group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Long Lunches
description: Peter Gordon hears an echo.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw Peter Gordon in February, he was taking us on a tour of the states. In this puzzle, he reveals an interesting find in a set of six phrases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mimi Swartz
title: How Texas Swaggered Into a Coronavirus Disaster
description: The state wanted to be among the first to reopen. It’s now dealing with the consequences.
content: HOUSTON — For one brief, delusional moment in early April, I felt a smidgen of support for my governor, Greg Abbott. Sure, part of me thought his plan to reopen the state after just a few weeks of lockdown was cuckoo. Medical experts warned of a surge in coronavirus cases if Texas did just that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Zaretsky
title: Montaigne Fled the Plague, and Found Himself
description: As disease and war ravaged the nation, he left town and invented the essay.
content: In the summer of 1585, the mayor of Bordeaux learned, from the comfort of his nearby chateau, that the bubonic plague had burst upon his city. Those who could were fleeing, he was told, while those who could not were “dying like flies.” What to do? His term in office, on the one hand, was nearly over and his last official duty was to attend the transition ceremony. On the other hand, perhaps his duty was with those still inside the city walls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew W. Kahrl
title: Who Will Get to Swim This Summer?
description: History is repeating itself as pools, beaches and clubs open — but mostly for the privileged few.
content: Like other crises in the past, the coronavirus pandemic has provided an opportunity for communities to act on their most exclusionary impulses. This summer, private pools and beach clubs, as well as public facilities in wealthier areas, are reopening with new measures to ensure that the general public stays out: hiring more security, aggressively checking beach tags and restricting access to residents only.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Can We Reach a Consensus on Gay Rights and Religion?
description: The A.C.L.U. says protections for religion already exist; a pastor sees possibility in congressional legislation. Also: Generation Z’s hopes and fears.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: China’s New National Security Law Looms Over Hong Kong
description: Chinese lawmakers could approve the law within days, threatening to curb free speech and protest in the territory after a year of political tumult.
content: Chinese lawmakers meeting from Sunday could approve a national security law as early as this week, drastically curbing political protest and dissent in Hong Kong and adding to China’s tensions with Western powers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: It’s Time for OSHA to Do Its Job
description: Readers urge the agency to step up to protect workers amid the Covid-19 pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Charles Webb, Elusive Author of ‘The Graduate,’ Dies at 81
description: His novel was turned into an era-defining movie, but he was never comfortable with its success, and he chose to live in poverty.
content: Charles Webb, who wrote the 1963 novel “The Graduate,” the basis for the hit 1967 film, and then spent decades running from its success, died on June 16 in East Sussex, England. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir and Jeffrey Gettleman
title: India Debates Skin-Tone Bias as Beauty Companies Alter Ads
description: America’s intense conversation on race has focused attention on a type of discrimination that has long vexed India.
content: NEW DELHI — Throughout the years she was growing up in southern India, Christy Jennifer, a producer with a media house in the city of Chennai, was traumatized by episodes of prejudice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Voters in Poland Appear to Force a Runoff for President
description: The incumbent, Andrzej Duda, will face Warsaw’s mayor, Rafal Trzaskowski, on July 12, according to exit polls. Turnout was high in Europe’s first major election during the pandemic.
content: WARSAW — Poland’s president, Andrzej Duda, fell short of securing a majority of the vote Sunday in Europe’s first socially distanced election, exit polls showed, forcing a runoff vote in two weeks against the second-place finisher, Mayor Rafal Trzaskowski of Warsaw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Linda Cristal, Who Starred in ‘High Chaparral,’ Dies at 89
description: To win the role of the fiery Victoria Cannon, she said, she threw away the script and “made up stories showing love, hate, passion, envy, jealousy, etc.”
content: Linda Cristal, an Argentine-born actress who played Victoria, the regal, fiery wife of the rancher Big John Cannon on the 1960s television series “The High Chaparral,” died on Saturday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Broadway League Pledges Change Amid National Uproar Over Racism
description: The organization will commission a comprehensive survey to get a handle on diversity onstage, backstage and in production offices.
content: The Broadway League, a trade association that is the closest thing to a governing body presiding over America’s biggest stages, has decided to undertake a sweeping audit of diversity in the industry in response to the unrest over racial injustice that is sweeping the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Ali Watkins
title: Why the $6 Billion N.Y.P.D. Is Now a Target of ‘Defund the Police’
description: The New York police have taken on a vast purview beyond crime fighting that includes schools and mental health. Officials are now rethinking that.
content: When someone in the grip of a mental health emergency behaves erratically in New York City, it is the Police Department that is often called in. When there are serious disciplinary problems in the schools, or when homeless people are found sleeping in the subways, police officers are asked to take over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Thomas Kaplan
title: Biden Campaign Says Just Over a Third of 2020 Staff Members Are People of Color
description: Mr. Biden released figures on Saturday after facing questions about racial diversity at the upper echelons of his campaign.
content: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. released statistics on the diversity of his presidential campaign staff on Saturday evening, announcing that 35 percent of his full-time staff members and 36 percent of his full-time senior staff members are people of color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Sunday: The BET Awards and ‘I’ll Be Gone in the Dark’
description: Tune into the 20th annual BET Awards, or watch a true crime documentary series on HBO.
content: 2020 BET AWARDS 8 p.m. on BET and CBS. While some awards have postponed their ceremonies, this annual show, which celebrates the work of black artists, athletes and entertainers, is still a go. Now in its 20th year, the BET Awards will feature performances by Alicia Keys, Future, DaBaby and more. Rather than sing from their couches, the artists prerecorded their own segments from all sorts of settings, using open venues, public spaces and, of course, their creativity. Drake leads with six nominations, followed by Megan Thee Stallion and Roddy Rich, who each have five. Other artists with multiple nods include Beyoncé, Nicki Minaj and Chris Brown. The comedian Amanda Seales hosts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Don’t Say You Weren’t Warned
description: Coronavirus cases are spiking in states that reopened quickly, threatening the country’s economic recovery.
content: Have a safe and socially distanced July Fourth. You know the rules, annoying as they are. And fresh outbreaks in many states prove the dangers of wishful thinking. Here’s what else you need to know for the week ahead in business and tech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Make a vegan ranch dressing, from Superiority Burger in New York, and use it to top roasted potatoes, grilled romaine or even your next burger.
content: Good morning. A number of years ago, my friend and colleague Tejal Rao met up with a sous chef named Julia Goldberg at the vegetarian restaurant Superiority Burger in New York, where Goldberg then worked. Tejal had come to learn the secrets of one of Goldberg’s most elegant creations: A vegan ranch dressing (above), “tangy and creamy,” Tejal wrote for The Times, “turbocharged with the familiar mouth-smacking umami of bottled ranch.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janet Maslin
title: When the Room With a View Is Kevin Kwan’s, Things Might Get Wild
description: “Sex and Vanity,” Kwan’s new novel, updates E.M. Forster’s classic with a multinational cast and a lot less restraint.
content: It’s been seven years since Kevin Kwan’s “Crazy Rich Asians” took the world of escapist shopaholic fantasy by storm. That was so long ago that Kwan’s funniest Hong Kong arriviste, Eddie Chen, could use Astor, Trump and Vanderbilt as the names of his dogs. That book, which grew into a wildly popular trilogy and film franchise, made the Marie Antoinette-ing of the Singaporean superrich both freakish and fascinating. So much about the extravagance and snobbery of the book’s clashing Asian elites was not globally known.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang W. Lee
title: Pride March in New York Protests Police Brutality
description: More than 1,000 people walked in the Queer Liberation March, a Pride celebration and anti-racism protest. A brief confrontation erupted with police as protesters gathered in Washington Square Park.
content: More than 1,000 people walked in the Queer Liberation March, a Pride celebration and anti-racism protest. A brief confrontation erupted with police as protesters gathered in Washington Square Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang W. Lee
title: Pride March in New York Protests Police Brutality
description: More than 1,000 people walked in the Queer Liberation March, a Pride celebration and anti-racism protest. A brief confrontation erupted with police as protesters gathered in Washington Square Park.
content: More than 1,000 people walked in the Queer Liberation March, a Pride celebration and anti-racism protest. A brief confrontation erupted with police as protesters gathered in Washington Square Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Chesapeake Energy, a Shale Pioneer, Files for Bankruptcy Protection
description: The company helped turn the United States into a gas exporter but became known for an illegal scheme to suppress the price of oil and gas leases.
content: HOUSTON — Chesapeake Energy, a pioneer in extracting natural gas from shale rock across the country, filed for bankruptcy protection on Sunday, unable to overcome a mountain of debt that became unsustainable after a decade of stubbornly low gas prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Senior
title: Trump’s Napalm Politics? They Began With Newt
description: Gingrich wrote the playbook for it all. The nastiness, the contempt for norms, the transformation of political opponents into enemies.
content: Approximately one billion news cycles ago — which is to say, on June 9 — a businesswoman named Marjorie Taylor Greene finished first in the Republican primary in Georgia’s deeply conservative 14th Congressional District, northwest of Atlanta, which means that after a runoff she’s all but assured a seat in the House of Representatives next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Matthew Abbott
title: Majestic Icon or Invasive Pest? A War Over Australia’s Wild Horses
description: Scientists say the animals, known as brumbies, must be culled because they are destroying rivers and endangering native wildlife. Rural activists call these efforts an attack on Australian heritage.
content: ANGLERS REST, Australia — Coming over the rise, Philip Maguire gripped the mane of his white gelding and rose on his heels to survey the bush land. He had hoped to be photographed mustering wild horses, but the animals weren’t playing along.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy and Lucy Tompkins
title: 1 Dead After Man Shoots Into Crowd at Breonna Taylor Protest Site
description: Video footage showed a man firing more than a dozen shots at a park in Louisville, Ky., where demonstrators were protesting Ms. Taylor’s shooting death by the police in March.
content: A fatal shooting in Louisville on Saturday night added a grim note to weeks of protests against police violence and particularly against the killing there in March of Breonna Taylor, an African-American emergency room technician shot to death by police in her home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi
title: With Flights Banned, Son Sails Solo Across Atlantic to Reach Father, 90
description: An Argentine man stuck in Portugal because of the virus travels for 85 days the only way he could: in a small boat.
content: BUENOS AIRES — Days after Argentina canceled all international passenger flights to shield the country from the new coronavirus, Juan Manuel Ballestero began his journey home the only way possible: He stepped aboard his small sailboat for what turned out to be an 85-day odyssey across the Atlantic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Florida’s Covid Cases Up Fivefold in 2 Weeks: ‘The Numbers Are Scary’
description: A surge in coronavirus cases has prompted officials to prohibit alcohol sales in bars and close Miami beaches for the coming holiday. But will it be enough?
content: MIAMI — John Delgado has slept in a tent in his backyard for 57 nights and counting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: ‘They Want to Kill Me’: Many Covid Patients Have Terrifying Delirium
description: Paranoid hallucinations plague many coronavirus patients in I.C.U.s, an experience that can slow recovery and increase risk of depression and cognitive issues.
content: Kim Victory was paralyzed on a bed and being burned alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Marty Baron Made The Post Great Again. Now, the News Is Changing.
description: The ultimate old-school editor is grappling with a moment of cultural reckoning.
content: Almost anyone who works in the Washington Post newsroom can look inside its publishing system, Methode, to see what stories are coming. And at the height of the furor over Brett Kavanaugh’s nomination to the Supreme Court in 2018, some who did saw a shocking article awaiting publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Trump Retweets Racist Video Showing Supporter Yelling ‘White Power’
description: The president later deleted the tweet, which once again showed his willingness to use social media to amplify some of the most hateful commentary of some of his followers, even at a moment of unrest.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Sunday retweeted a video of one of his supporters yelling “White power!,” once again using the vast reach of his social media platforms to inflame racial divisions in a nation roiled by weeks of protests about police brutality against black people and demands for social justice reforms.
source.name: The New York Times
